p.text: The provisions of this Part comprise uniform rules developed under the auspices of the Australian Council of Chief Justices.
[Pt 33 am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[11], effective 9 June 2006]

row.entry: These rules govern the general form, content and service of subpoenas issued for the purpose of proceedings. Rule 33.13 provides a special procedure for obtaining production of documents held by a court.

entry.emph: Setting aside and variation of subpoenas — Rule 33.4

row.entry: This rule provides for applications to set aside subpoenas and make other orders varying the extent of the compliance they require.
This rule requires a subpoena to be served personally on the addressees. Thereafter, the party who issued the subpoena must also serve it on the other parties to the proceedings.

entry.emph: Compliance, and failure to comply, with subpoenas — Rules 33.6–33.7, 33.11–33.12

row.entry: These rules regulate the scope of the obligation to comply with a subpoena, the entitlement to the expenses involved in compliance, and the sanctions for failure to comply with a subpoena.

entry.emph: Inspection, copying, removal, return, and disposal of documents and things — Rules 33.8–33.10

row.entry: These rules govern the procedure for the removal, return, inspection, copying and disposal of documents and things produced under a subpoena.

This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1. This part (other than rr 33.3(1), 33.3(8), 33.6(1), 33.7 and if the issuing party is the Crown rr 33.2(3) , 33.5 and 33.11 ) applies to criminal proceedings in SCA Third Schedule and to Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR (summary jurisdiction): see SCR Pt 75 r 3 . This part also applies to the issue of a subpoena under s 27A of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010: UCPR r 47.4.
The Part is based on the former SCR Pt 37. Those rules nationally harmonised subpoena rules developed by the Council of the Chief Justices.

p.text: In this Part:
means the person who is the subject of the order expressed in a subpoena.

means a sum of money or its equivalent, such as pre-paid travel, sufficient to meet the reasonable expenses of the addressee of attending court as required by the subpoena and returning after so attending.
means an officer of the court who is empowered to issue a subpoena on behalf of the court.
means the party at whose request a subpoena is issued.
, in relation to proceedings in respect of which a subpoena is sought or issued, means:
in relation to the Supreme Court, the principal registrar, and
in relation to the Industrial Court, the industrial registrar referred to in section 207 of the Industrial Relations Act 1996, and
in relation to the District Court:
the principal registrar, or

the registrar of the District Court for the proclaimed place (within the meaning of the District Court Act 1973) where the subpoena is issued, or where the subpoena is returnable, whichever is applicable, and
in relation to the Local Court, the registrar of the Local Court for the venue where the subpoena was issued.
[def am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 5 October 2007 ; Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], [5], effective 6 July 2009 ; Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[6], effective 1 February 2010]
means an order in writing requiring the addressee:
to attend to give evidence, or
to produce the subpoena or a copy of it and a document or thing, or
to do both of those things,
and includes a summons to that effect under section 165 of the Industrial Relations Act 1996.
[def am Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[7], effective 1 February 2010]
To the extent that a subpoena requires the addressee to attend to give evidence, it is called a subpoena to attend to give evidence.
To the extent that a subpoena requires the addressee to produce the subpoena or a copy of it and a document or thing, it is called a subpoena to produce.
See also rules 7.3 , 10.12 , 10.20 , 31.20 , 31.22 and 31.23 with respect to the issue and service of subpoenas.

The approved forms are Form 25 (Subpoena to attend to give evidence), Form 26A (Subpoena to produce with subpoena notice and declaration) and Form 27A (Subpoena to attend to give evidence and produce with subpoena notice and declaration). See also Practice Note SC Gen 18 — Production of and access to subpoenaed material and returning exhibits and subpoenaed material in civil proceedings and Practice Note SC Gen 19 — Subpoenas — proposed access orders and the return of subpoena list.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.2] r 33.2 Issuing of subpoena (cf SCR Part 37, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Issuing of subpoena (cf SCR Part 37, rule 2)

p.text: The court may, in any proceeding, by subpoena order the addressee:
to attend to give evidence as directed by the subpoena, or
to produce the subpoena or a copy of it and any document or thing as directed by the subpoena, or
to do both of those things.
An issuing officer must not issue a subpoena:
if the court has made an order, or there is a rule of the court, having the effect of requiring that the proposed subpoena:
not be issued, or
not be issued without the leave of the court and that leave has not been given, or
requiring the production of a document or thing in the custody of the court or another court.
The issuing officer must seal with the seal of the court, or otherwise authenticate, a sufficient number of copies of the subpoena for service and proof of service.
A subpoena is taken to have been issued on its being sealed or otherwise authenticated in accordance with subrule (3).

level.toc-caption: [33.2.5] Issue of subpoenas — when leave required

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 68.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.1, r 7.3(1), r 7.3(3).

heading.title: Issue of subpoenas — when leave required

p.text: These rules complement CPA s 68 and regulate the powers and procedures for the issue of subpoenas in proceedings in the court. Parties may conduct proceedings either in person, by a solicitor, or in certain circumstances, by an authorised person: see r 7.1 of the UCPR. But only a party who is represented by a solicitor can issue a subpoena without leave: see r 7.3(1) . In proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court leave is always required to issue a subpoena: r 7.3(3) .
The procedure for obtaining leave, together with a reference to the required forms, is summarised in [7.3.10] .
Legislation cited in [33.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 50.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 s 27, 27A, ss 6(1).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 47.4, 47.5.

Where a court refers proceedings to arbitration under CPA s 38, the referring court may issue, and enforce, orders for the attendance of witnesses and the production of documents for the purpose of the arbitration: see CPA s 50 .

Where the arbitration proceedings arise under a commercial arbitration agreement, similar orders for attendance and production may be made either by the Supreme Court or, if the parties have agreed in writing (including in the arbitration agreement itself) by either the District Court or the Local Court: see the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 ss 6(1) and 27A ). The arbitral tribunal itself may also seek the assistance of the relevant court in taking evidence: s 27 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010. See also UCPR rr 47.4 and 47.5 .

level.toc-caption: [33.2.15] Related powers to obtain production of documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 36.

heading.title: Related powers to obtain production of documents

p.text: Orders for production may also be made under s 36 of the Evidence Act in relation to persons present at hearings: see [34.1.10] .
Legislation cited in [33.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 21.10, r 21.3, r 33.3, 34.1.

Parties may obtain documents from opposing parties by way of discovery (UCPR r 21.3 ), in response to a notice to produce (UCPR rr 21.10 and 34.1 ) or by the issue of a subpoena under the present rule. A party may not use a subpoena as a substitute for discovery, or as a means of questioning the adequacy of a party’s discovery: see [33.3.25] and [33.4.10] . Provided the subpoena sufficiently identifies the relevant documents (in accordance with UCPR r 33.3 ; see also [33.4.20]–[33.4.25] ), it is not objectionable merely because its purpose is to impugn the adequacy of the opposing party’s discovery: Bengalla Mining Co Pty Ltd v Barclay Mowlem Construction Ltd [2001] NSWSC 93; BC200100556 at [16].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.3] r 33.3 Form of subpoena (cf SCR Part 37, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Form of subpoena (cf SCR Part 37, rule 3)

p.text: A subpoena must be in the approved form.
A subpoena must not be addressed to more than one person.
Unless the court orders otherwise, a subpoena must identify the addressee by name or by description of office or position.
A subpoena to produce must:
identify the document or thing to be produced, and
specify the date, time and place for production.
A subpoena to attend to give evidence must specify the date, time and place for attendance.
The date specified in a subpoena must be the date of trial or any other date as permitted by the court.
The place specified for production may be the court or the address of any person authorised to take evidence in the proceeding as permitted by the court.
The last date for service of a subpoena:
is the date falling 5 days before the earliest date on which an addressee is required to comply with the subpoena or an earlier or later date fixed by the court, and
must be specified in the subpoena.
[subr (8) subst Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[7], effective 5 April 2007]
If the addressee is a corporation, the corporation must comply with the subpoena by its appropriate or proper officer.

The approved forms are Form 25 (Subpoena to attend to give evidence), Form 26A (Subpoena to produce with subpoena notice and declaration) and Form 27A (Subpoena to attend to give evidence and produce with subpoena notice and declaration). The requirements previously in Form 28 (Subpoena notice and declaration) have now been incorporated in Forms 26A and 27A. See also Supreme Court Practice Notes SC Gen 18 (Supreme Court — Production of and access to subpoenaed material and returning exhibits and subpoenaed material in civil proceedings) and SC Gen 19 (Subpoenas — Proposed access orders and the return of subpoena lists) and District Court Practice Note DC (Civil) 8 (Early return of subpoenas).

level.toc-caption: [33.3.3] Access to documents produced on subpoena

heading.title: Access to documents produced on subpoena

p.text: Practice Note SC Gen 19 requires that a subpoena to produce or to give evidence and produce must include either a proposed access order for the documents to be produced and the reasons for that order (eg party might be entitled to claim privilege) or a default access order: see also Practice Note DC (Civil) 8. In the Supreme Court the default access order is “general access to all parties” (including permission to photocopy). In the District Court the default access order is that “the issuing party [is] to have access for 7 days, thereafter, in the absence of further application, access to all parties”. The default access order to be made is the one appropriate for the jurisdiction that the subpoena was issued in: see also Forms 26A and 27A.
Legislation cited in [33.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 34.1.

The subpoena power extends to any person named in the subpoena. Thus, subpoenas may be issued to the opposing party (although the notice to produce provided for in r 34.1 will usually be a more convenient procedure to adopt) and, in the special case where an insurer has assumed the conduct of the proceedings, a subpoena may even be issued on the insurer's behalf to the named insured: Mulligan v Lancaster [1969] 2 NSWR 284; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 343 .

A subpoena to give evidence requires that the recipient attend for the purpose of attending court and giving evidence on oath. No oath can meaningfully be administered to a corporation and therefore no subpoena to give evidence can validly be served on a corporation: Fieldhouse v FCT (1989) 25 FCR 187; 90 ALR 1 ; McDonald v Australian Securities Commission (No 2) (1994) 48 FCR 210; 120 ALR 515 at 519 . A corporation can be required to produce documents. Where production by a corporation is required, it is the practice to address the subpoena to the corporation and to require production of the documents by the corporation's “proper officer”: Penn-Texas Corp v Murat Anstalt (No 2) [1964] 2 QB 647 ; Rochfort v Trade Practices Commission (1982) 153 CLR 134 at 146; 43 ALR 659 . A person who is otherwise a “proper officer” of the corporation may be personally entitled to claim the privilege against incrimination, but the privilege is not available to the corporation, which must still comply with the subpoena — even if that involves the appointment of a receiver for the purpose: R v Ronen (2004) 62 NSWLR 707; [2004] NSWCCA 67; BC200409653 . A subpoena may properly be directed to a director — rather than to the corporation itself — where the director effectively controls the company or has full and unrestricted possession of the documents in question: Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 .

level.toc-caption: [33.3.15] Documents — related to credit of witness

heading.title: Documents — related to credit of witness

p.text: A subpoena may be issued for the purpose of obtaining documents relevant to the credit of a witness, provided the documents are sufficiently described, and the subpoena is not otherwise oppressive: Re Emma Silver Mining Co (1875) LR 10 Ch App 194 at 197; Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt (1978) 18 ALR 555; 45 FLR 174 ; R v Saleam (1989) 16 NSWLR 14 at 19; 39 A Crim R 406 ; Carter v Hayes (1994) 61 SASR 451; 72 A Crim R 387 at 389 ; Hunt v Judge Russell (1995) 63 SASR 402 at 410 ; Fried v National Australia Bank (2000) 175 ALR 194 .

A subpoena only requires a person to produce those documents and things that are within their custody or control. Moreover, where a person has custody of documents on behalf of another, the subpoena ought ordinarily be addressed to the person who has ultimate control of them. Thus, a subpoena for production of documents ought usually be addressed to an employer rather than to the individual employee responsible for their immediate custody. Similarly, in the case of a partnership, a subpoena for production should be addressed to all the partners rather than to one individual partner: Rochfort v Trade Practices Commission (1982) 153 CLR 134; 43 ALR 659 .
Legislation cited in [33.3.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.4.

A subpoena to produce is not a substitute for discovery and must identify, with reasonable particularity, the documents whose production is required: Lane v Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales (1981) 148 CLR 245 at 257; 35 ALR 322 . A subpoena that does not satisfy this requirement is liable to be set aside: Elder v Carter (1890) 25 QBD 194 ; Burchard v Macfarlane [1891] 2 QB 241 ; Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564; 55 WN (NSW) 215 ; O'Born v Cmr for Government Transport (1959) 77 WN (NSW) 81; McAuliffe v McAuliffe (1973) 4 ACTR 9 ; National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372 and on appeal National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind (1979) 141 CLR 648; 24 ALR 86 . See further the notes to r 33.4 .
Legislation cited in [33.3.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 2.1, UCPR r 33.3(6), UCPR rr 33.7–33.9.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 56.

The rule permits the issue of a subpoena that requires the production of documents at any time permitted by the court. There is no basis for any general limitation that would restrict production to the actual date of the trial: UCPR r 33.3(6) . Compare Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt (1978) 18 ALR 555; 45 FLR 174 and Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 with Botany Bay Instrumentation & Control Pty Ltd v Stewart [1984] 3 NSWLR 98 . Indeed, the general discretionary considerations mandated by CPA s 56 and UCPR r 2.1 and the specific requirements of various Practice Notes, together with the facilitative procedures in UCPR rr 33.7–33.9 , reflect the common and desirable practice for subpoenas to be issued and made returnable well before the date fixed for trial: Pyoja Pty Ltd v 284 Bronte Road Developments Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 831; BC200606373 at [6] . In the District Court, the early issue and return of subpoenas is the subject of a specific Practice Note — DC (Civil) No 8 Early Return of Subpoenas: see [DC (Civil) 8] in vol 2.
