Additional costs (applicable on a case by case basis, where compliance is in response to an order for short service); plus
Courier costs (applicable on a case by case basis, where compliance in a timely fashion requires the incurring of courier costs)

text.emph: Subpoena to give evidence (where personal service on an agency officer is required)

p.text: When a subpoena is served on a departmental officer in his or her capacity as an officer of a relevant agency, that agency will not accept service of the subpoena.
The rules relating to personal service apply.
The ordinary salary of any staff member attending court and any additional expenses associated with their attendance may be required to be paid.
Any expenses involved in travel and accommodation of a staff member to attend court may be required to be paid.”

The New South Wales Police Service has asked that solicitors contact the police concerned before issuing subpoenas to avoid unnecessary expense and inconvenience, as it frequently happens that police have already been subpoenaed to attend other courts or are absent overseas or are incapacitated to such an extent that their attendance at court is not possible. The New South Wales Police Service provides a service in accepting subpoenas at the counter of Police Headquarters on behalf of police officers. The Police Service may withdraw the service of accepting subpoenas at Police Headquarters if solicitors do not comply with the request for payment of witness expenses incurred by police officers.

Five clear working days are required when serving civil subpoenas at Police Headquarters, otherwise the subpoenas should be served at the relevant police station or branch. No exceptions will be made unless a court order is served along with the subpoena.

Reasonable time should be given when serving a subpoena in a criminal matter. All subpoenas should provide accurate and precise information to avoid unnecessary delays in the processing of the subpoenas.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.4] r 33.4 Setting aside or other relief (cf SCR Part 37, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Setting aside or other relief (cf SCR Part 37, rule 4)

p.text: The court may, on the application of a party or any person having a sufficient interest, set aside a subpoena in whole or in part, or grant other relief in respect of it.
An application under subrule (1) must be made on notice to the issuing party.
The court may order that the applicant give notice of the application to any other party or to any other person having a sufficient interest.

level.toc-caption: [33.4.5] Appeal — against refusal to set aside subpoena

heading.title: Appeal — against refusal to set aside subpoena

p.text: If a judge rules against an applicant to set aside a subpoena, the Court of Appeal will not delay the hearing of the main proceedings by entertaining an appeal, nor will it expedite the appeal: Partnership Pacific Ltd v Killen (NSWSC, Moffit P, Reynolds and Hutley JJA, 10 April 1979, CA No 112/79, unreported) (see behind guide card “Practice Decisions” in Vol 3). Nevertheless, where an application to set aside a subpoena is refused, the applicant may seek leave to appeal against the refusal even though they are not a party to the proceedings: Senior v Holdsworth; Ex parte Independent Television News Ltd [1976] QB 23 at 32; [1975] 2 All ER 1009 ; Re Markham; Markham v Markham (1880) 16 Ch D 1 ; Re Security Insurance Co [1894] 2 Ch 410 ; Witness v Marsden (2000) 49 NSWLR 429 at 442–6; [2000] NSWCA 52; BC200001106 at [61], [74] .
Legislation cited in [33.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 21, rr 34.1, 34.2.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 68.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 36.

The power to set aside a subpoena complements a range of procedures designed to ensure that information relevant to the proper determination of the proceedings is available to the parties and the court. Those procedures include discovery under Pt 21 , orders for production on notice under rr 34.1 and 34.2 , and production pursuant to CPA s 68 and Evidence Act 1995 s 36 . All of these procedures are intended to facilitate the proper and efficient conduct of the proceedings. Correspondingly, that purpose marks a limit on the proper use of subpoenas. They cannot be used where they constitute an abuse of process. The issue of a subpoena may constitute an abuse of process:

where it has not been served bona fide for the purpose of obtaining relevant evidence: R v Baines [1909] 1 KB 258; [1908–10] All ER Rep 328; R v Hove Justices; Ex parte Donne [1967] 2 All ER 1253 (n); (1967) 131 JP 460 ; Botany Bay Instrumentation & Control Pty Ltd v Stewart [1984] 3 NSWLR 98 ;

where it is not issued for the purpose of a pending trial, hearing or application: Central News Co v Eastern News Telegraph Co [1884] WN 23; Elder v Carter (1890) 62 LT 516; 25 QBD 194 ; Botany Bay Instrumentation & Control Pty Ltd v Stewart , above; (although the fact that the subpoena is issued and made returnable prior to the actual hearing does not necessarily mean that it is being used for an improper purpose: Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt (1978) 18 ALR 555; 45 FLR 174 ; Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 ; Hughes v Western Australian Cricket Assn Inc (1986) 66 ALR 541; (1986) ATPR ¶40–725 );
where there is an alternative statutory procedure to compel the attendance of witnesses or the production of documents: R v Hurle-Hobbs [1945] KB 165 ;
where the subpoena is oppressive: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372 (documents sought having no conceivable relation to the proceedings);
where the subpoena is served upon defendants in proceedings for the recovery of a penalty: Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 53 ALR 214; 15 A Crim R 172 ;

where the subpoena requires the production of things that have come into the person’s possession in the course of the conduct of proceedings and are subject to the implied undertaking referred to in [21.7.5] : Lemery Holdings Pth Ltd v Reliance Financial Services Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1100; BC200809210 at [23], [28] .

It sometimes occurs that parties, or their legal advisers, develop a special expertise related to particular types of litigation. This may result in the accumulation of relevant documents and the development of management systems for their control and use. It will generally not be an appropriate exercise of the subpoena power to attempt to obtain documents of this kind. Because the documents will generally have been brought into existence for the purpose of other litigation between different parties, it will have, at best, only marginal relevance to the factual issues arising at any particular case. In so far as documents of this kind have a general reference to the subject matter of the litigation, the party or lawyer who holds it has a legitimate interest in preserving for itself the benefit of its past experience and expertise: Woods v Wilfred Hanoldt (1995) 11 NSWCCR 161; BC9504247 (abuse of process in issuing a subpoena); Hickman v Taylor (1946) 329 US 495 at 510 (discovery of documents, noted at 107 LQR 370 at 372).

It is not a legitimate purpose to seek the production of documents that are sought solely because of their capacity to impugn the general credit of a witness: Re Bird and Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Comm (2006) 91 ALD 691; [2006] AATA 109; BC200600402 . However, the emphasis in this restriction is on the notion of an exclusive challenge to the witness’s general credibility. There is no such restriction on the production of documents that “throw light” on the particular credibility of the witness’s evidence in the proceedings: Mackintosh v Commissioner of Police (NSW) [2010] NSWSC 1064; BC201007038 at [11]–[17] (subpoena seeking witness’ criminal history records). The distinction between general credit and particular credibility is not always able to be precisely drawn: for example in Bird, above, the documents sought included details of the witness’s service history and reports relating to the period of service during which the contentious events occurred. The AAT accepted the “possibility that some of the documents among the service records could possibly throw some light on the issues to be determined at the hearing”. Nevertheless the summons was set aside because of (i) the generality of the documents sought (ii) the certainty that a substantial proportion of them could have no relevance to the proceedings (iii) the fact that the documents sought contained personal information whose disclosure the addressees reasonably objected and (iv) the inability of the applicant to demonstrate the probable existence of relevant documents. The tribunal concluded that the summons was “more speculative than reasonable”: at [27]. See also Mandic v Phillis (2005) 225 ALR 760; 88 ALD 676; [2005] FCA 1279; BC200506793 (an employer in an appeal against a judgment in sexual harassment proceedings, sought to summons a psychological profile that had been prepared of the complainant by another employer — found that the summons should be set aside on the basis of (i) its tangential relevance to the proceedings (ii) the commercial and privacy interest of the new employer and (iii) the privacy and health interests of the complainant). Those decisions may be contrasted with a subpoena to produce records of convictions for dishonesty — at least where there is a sufficient basis to apprehend that such documents exist: Liristis v Gadelrabb [2009] NSWSC 441; BC200904733 (subpoena to Police Commissioner — serious credibility issues in the proceedings — reason to apprehend prior perjury conviction).

One of the common grounds for seeking to set aside a subpoena is that it constitutes impermissible “fishing”: see per Owen J in Associated Dominions Assurance Society Pty Ltd v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1955) 72 WN (NSW) 250 at 254. But this pejorative has been accorded such a fluid interpretation, that its use perhaps more obscures than illuminates the principles involved. Perhaps the essential idea is better captured by contrasting “trawl netting” with “rod fishing” and, understood in the light of that contrast it leads on to another common basis of objection to a subpoena — that it cannot properly be used as a “substitute for discovery”. This expression has been accorded a changing emphasis over time: compare Hedges v Burchell (1913) 17 CLR 327 at 332; 20 ALR 4 and Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt (1978) 18 ALR 555 at 569; 45 FLR 174 ; its essential accuracy requires elaboration. The fundamental principle is that subpoenas should identify the documents sought with reasonable particularity: Spencer Motors Pty Ltd v LNC Industries Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 921 at 926 . A subpoena that does not describe the documents with sufficient particularity is liable to be set aside: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372 and on appeal National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind (1979) 141 CLR 648; 24 ALR 86 ; Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564 at 573–4; 55 WN (NSW) 215 . This requirement for “reasonable particularity” distinguishes the subpoena power from the discovery obligation between parties — the essential difference being that only the discovery obligation, and not that imposed by a subpoena, can require a person to assess whether unspecified documents are “relevant to a fact in issue” in the proceedings: Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 at 718A; Bengalla Mining Co Pty Ltd v Barclay Mowlem Construction Ltd [2001] NSWSC 93; BC200100556 at [16] . The requirement for particularity also highlights that non-parties should not be subjected to “fishing/netting” — in the sense of unrestricted access to their private documents. However, the emphasis is on the requirement for “reasonable particularity”. A subpoena that does not precisely describe the documents required, or describes them only in general terms, is not necessarily improper: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372 .

level.toc-caption: [33.4.25] Identification of things — by relationship or reference

heading.title: Identification of things — by relationship or reference

p.text: The requirement that a subpoena must identify the things to be produced should not be narrowly interpreted. The subpoena itself should be interpreted in a broad, common-sense way and from the perspective of its likely interpretation by the intended recipient. In determining whether a subpoena contains a sufficient “identification”, the court should consider how it is likely to be interpreted by its recipient: Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 at 720; acting as a reasonable person with the knowledge of the surrounding circumstances: Re Southern Equities Corp Ltd (in liq); Bond v England (1997) 24 ACSR 472; 15 ACLC 1430 . This means the court can take into account all of the relevant circumstances, including the identity of the recipient and its capacity to produce the documents, as well as the description of the documents called for: R v Barton [1981] 2 NSWLR 414 ; Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt (1978) 18 ALR 555 at 570–1; 45 FLR 174 . It follows that a subpoena is not necessarily improper merely because it uses expressions such as “referring to” or “relating to” in attempting to describe the documents whose production is required: Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd, above; Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt, above ALR at 572–3; cf Finnie v Dalglish [1982] 1 NSWLR 400 : cf Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564; 55 WN (NSW) 215 ; Burchard v Macfarlane [1891] 2 QB 241 at 247 . Whether or not such a description is proper may depend on the nature of the “relationship” specified in the subpoena. The subpoena will be unlikely to satisfy the requirement of reasonable particularity if it requires the recipient to identify documents by reference to their relevance to “issues” between the parties in the proceedings — because this (impermissibly) imposes an obligation in the nature of discovery: Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 at 718; Lucas Industries Ltd v Hewitt (1978) 18 ALR 555 at 569; 45 FLR 174 ; Bank of New South Wales v Withers (1981) 35 ALR 21; 52 FLR 207 ; R v Barton [1981] 2 NSWLR 414 ; Gilligan v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (1990) 101 FLR 139 (subpoena to Secretary of the Department of Defence — substantial search and discrete judgment in relation to each document required; claim for public interest immunity upheld); Pancontinental Mining Ltd v Burns (1994) 124 ALR 471; 14 ACSR 545; 34 ALD 239 at 256; BC9406045 . But a subpoena may properly require the production of documents that “relate to” a particular fact or subject matter (Spencer Motors Pty Ltd v LNC Industries Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 921 at 929 ), provided that the production is reasonably necessary and the scope of the documents required does not impose an oppressive obligation on the recipient: Arhill Pty Ltd v General Terminal Co Pty Ltd (1990) 23 NSWLR 545.

level.toc-caption: [33.4.30] Permissible scope of subpoenas — documents of apparent relevance

heading.title: Permissible scope of subpoenas — documents of apparent relevance

p.text: The contrast between the permissible scope of a subpoena for production, and what constitutes impermissible generality, is essentially a distinction between documents in whose relevance there is “a reasonable cause” to believe and, on the other hand, documents whose potential relevance is essentially speculative: Cosco Holdings Pty Ltd v Cmr of Taxation (1997) 37 ATR 432; BC9707273 : City of Sydney v Streetscape Projects (Aust) Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 364; BC201104008 at [10] and [25] (endorsing the substance of the present note). This basic criterion has been given various descriptions in the authorities. These descriptions include the propositions that the documents:

have the capacity to “throw light on the issues in the main case”: Trade Practices Commission v Arnotts Ltd (No 2) (1989) 88 ALR 90 at 103; 21 FCR 306; BC8908420 ; GB v Western Sydney Area Health Service [2010] NSWSC 181; BC201001309 at [96] (potential causal contribution of genetic disorder — sibling’s treatment records for apparently similar disorder — permissible subpoena)
are “connected with or pertinent to” the proceedings: Re VBN and Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (2005) 92 ALD 455; 44 AAR 212; [2005] AATA 1060; BC200512100 ;
could “reasonably be expected to throw some light on the issues in the proceedings”: Re Marnotta and Secretary, Dept of Health and Ageing [2004] AATA 800 at [42] ;
are necessary for disposing fairly of the proceedings: Arhill Pty Ltd v General Terminal Co Pty Ltd (1990) 23 NSWLR 545 ;
have “a sufficient apparent connection” with the issues in the proceedings: White v Tulloch (1995) 19 Fam LR 696; 127 FLR 105; FLC ¶92-640 ;

may reasonably be regarded as “on the cards” that the documents will materially assist the resolution of the issues in the proceedings: Alister v R (1984) 154 CLR 404; (1983) 50 ALR 41; 5 ALN No 245; BC8300122 ; Saleam v R (1989) 16 NSWLR 14; (1989) 39 A Crim R 406 at 409 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v Chidgey (2008) 182 A Crim R 536; [2008] NSWCCA 65; BC200801976 .

level.toc-caption: [33.4.32] Burdensome and oppressive subpoenas — setting aside

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.4.32] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 57.

heading.title: Burdensome and oppressive subpoenas — setting aside

p.text: Despite the requirements of either substantive or adjectival relevance, the subpoena power has considerable permissive breadth and flexibility. The discretionary power requires sensible judgment about whether the production sought is genuinely required and will comply with the overriding purpose set out in CPA s 56 and objects of case management at CPA s 57 . This task is not new, though its emphasis sometimes changes according to the prevailing judicial climate. It is to balance, that is to strike an apparently reasonable compromise between, the burdens imposed on complying third parties and the proper exercise of the statutorily mandated function. Relevant considerations that will inform that assessment will be:
the terms of the summons and the scope of the obligation they appear to impose;
the apprehended or actual burden and cost of compliance;
the identity of the addressee and their relationship (ie their degree of association with the parties and their connection with the subject matter of the proceedings);
the degree of apparent relevance of the material sought.
See Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc v Southern Pacific Hotel Corporation Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 710 at 719 .

A subpoena may be set aside as oppressive where it imposes an unduly onerous obligation upon a person to collect and produce the documents sought: Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564; 55 WN (NSW) 215 ; see also Lee v Angas (1866) LR2Eq 59; [1866] WN 131a ; Re Emma Silver Mining Co (1875) LR 10 Ch App 194. When dealing with the concept of “oppression” it is necessary to bear in mind that the criteria of “sufficient relevance” and “undue burden” are related, rather than disjunctive, concepts. Assessing whether production of a category of documents will impose an “undue burden” necessarily requires consideration of the nature and extent of the documents sought, the extent and the cost of exercise involved in their identification, collection and production, and the circumstances in which that exercise is required to be conducted. Even a subpoena to produce relevant documents may be regarded as oppressive if it involves numerous documents and would unduly impinge on a party’s preparation for, or conduct of, the proceedings: Tony Azzi Automobiles Pty Ltd v Volvo Car Australia Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 283; BC200602227 at [8] .
Legislation cited in [33.4.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 s 16(3).
(CTH) Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 s 207, s 208(1)(b)(ii).

Statutory prohibitions against the disclosure of information obtained in the course of government business will not generally be sufficient to prevent orders for production and inspection in legal proceedings: Sydney Water Corporation v Persons Listed in the Schedules trading as Pricewaterhouse Coopers [2008] NSWSC 361; BC200802791 (Auditor-General required to produce documents in compliance with subpoena despite s 38(1) of the Public Finance and Audit Act 1983); Potts v Dennis Jones & Co Pty Ltd (1995) 58 FCR 61; 17 ACSR 770 (documents obtained by the ASC — power to prohibit publication); Marcel v Cmr of Police of the Metropolis [1992] Ch 225; [1992] 1 All ER 72 (documents obtained by police). This is so unless the legislation contains a clear contrary indication: Canadian Pacific Tobacco Co Ltd v Stapleton (1952) 86 CLR 1; [1953] ALR 603 (s 16 of the Income Tax and Social Service Contribution Act 1936); Miller v Miller (1978) 141 CLR 269; 22 ALR 119 (Telephonic Communications (Interception) Act 1960); Irvin v Whitrod [1978] Qd R 137 ; Parkes Management Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd [1979] 1 NSWLR 274 at 275–7 ; Federal Cmr of Taxation v Nestle Australia Ltd (1986) 12 FCR 257 at 261; 69 ALR 445 ; Sanko Steamship Co Ltd v Sumitomo Australia Ltd (1992) 37 FCR 353 . Examples of statutory provisions that unambiguously preclude the production of documents in answer to a curial subpoena include Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 s 16(3) and Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 s 207 (subject to the consent of the person concerned: see s 208(1)(b)(ii) ). As to the scope of the directions power in permitting orders requiring parties to consent to disclosure by statutory authorities see [2.1.10] . Where public authorities are served with subpoenas relating to documents they have obtained in the exercise of statutory powers, (and where the documents may lawfully be produced despite the statutory prohibition) they should notify the persons who are otherwise entitled to the documents so that they have an opportunity to raise any objections to production or inspection in response to the subpoena: Marcel , above.

level.toc-caption: [33.4.40] Standing to set aside subpoena — addressee of subpoena

heading.title: Standing to set aside subpoena — addressee of subpoena

p.text: The recipient of a subpoena has sufficient standing to apply to set it aside, including standing to seek “other relief” such as a “pseudonym” order: Witness v Marsden (2000) 49 NSWLR 429; [2000] NSWCA 52; BC200001106 at [48]–[51], [61]–[82], [112] (a prisoner witness attending pursuant to a subpoena). The power to set aside applies to both subpoenas to give evidence: Purnell Brothers Pty Ltd v Transport Engineers Pty Ltd (1984) 73 FLR 160 ; R v Baines [1909] 1 KB 258; [1908–10] All ER Rep 328 (witnesses unable to give material evidence); Raymond v Tapson (1882) 22 Ch D 430 (subpoena properly issued to solicitor who previously acted for both parties); R v Lewes Justices; Ex parte Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1972] 1 QB 232 (likely inability of witnesses to give material evidence); Witness v Marsden (2000) 49 NSWLR 429; [2000] NSWCA 52; BC200001106 (witness fearing death or physical injury or an unnecessary loss of liberty); and to subpoenas to produce documents: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372; Burchard v Macfarlane [1891] 2 QB 241 ; Senior v Holdsworth; Ex parte Independent Television News Ltd [1976] QB 23; [1975] 2 All ER 1009 .

level.toc-caption: [33.4.45] Standing to set aside subpoena — party

heading.title: Standing to set aside subpoena — party

p.text: The present rule specifically permits a party to apply to set aside a subpoena, subject to satisfying the court that they have a sufficient interest. The rule thereby resolves the conflicting authorities as to whether a party has standing to apply to set aside a subpoena addressed to a non-party. On the one hand, the power to move to set aside an oppressive or irrelevant subpoena had been characterised as merely a part of the court's inherent power to control its own procedure and that any party may apply to prevent the improper use of the court's coercive subpoena powers: Compsyd Pty Ltd v Streamline Travel Service Pty Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 648; Botany Bay Instrumentation & Control Pty Ltd v Stewart [1984] 3 NSWLR 98 ; Trade Practices Commission v Kimberley Homes Pty Ltd (FCA, Hill J, 19 July 1989, unreported); Fried v National Australia Bank (2000) 175 ALR 194; [2000] FCA 911; BC200003759 and see discussion in 61 ALJ 747. The cases which reject the existence of such a power include: Jonal Properties Pty Ltd v MS McLeod Holdings Pty Ltd (1994) 62 SASR 306 ; Re ACI International Ltd (1986) 11 ACLR 240 ; Residues Treatment & Trading Co Ltd v Southern Resources Ltd (1989) 52 SASR 54; 15 ACLR 416 .

level.toc-caption: [33.4.50] Costs — of application to set aside or resist inspection

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.4.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.27.

heading.title: Costs — of application to set aside or resist inspection

p.text: The court has inherent jurisdiction to award costs of an application to set aside a subpoena — either for or against the applicant: Darcey v Pre-Term Foundation Clinic [1983] 2 NSWLR 497 (subpoena under the Justices Act 1902); R v Barbaro (1991) 108 ACTR 1 (subpoena in criminal proceedings); Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 879; BC200606784 . The court may also order costs in relation to an unsuccessful privilege claim concerning matters sought in a subpoena: ACP Magazines Pty Ltd v Motion [2000] NSWSC 1169; BC200007600 at [34] ; Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) , above: as to the costs of complying with a subpoena see UCPR r 42.27 .

level.toc-caption: [33.4.55] Expert witness — application to set aside subpoena addressed to

heading.title: Expert witness — application to set aside subpoena addressed to

p.text: As a general rule, the court will not require an expert to give expert evidence against their wishes in a case where they have had no connection with the facts or the history of the matter in dispute: Seyfang v GD Searle & Co [1973] QB 148 at 152 ; Lively Ltd v City of Munich [1976] 2 All ER 857; Re Forsyth [1984] 2 NSWLR 327 . However, there is no property in a witness and an expert who has been retained by one party is a compellable witness at the suit of the other party. No privilege attaches to the expert's evidence or to any non-privileged documents upon which their opinion has been based: Harmony Shipping Co SA v Davis [1979] 3 All ER 177 ; MacDonald Construction Co Ltd v Lathe Plastering Co Ltd (1972) 27 DLR (3d) 253.

level.toc-caption: [33.4.60] Notice of application to set aside a subpoena

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.4.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 18.2(2).

heading.title: Notice of application to set aside a subpoena

p.text: The express requirement to give notice to the issuing party, and the provision to order notice to be given to other parties, when coupled with the nature of the application, means that almost of necessity the notice be written and in the form of a notice of motion. If elements of urgency arise, consideration can be given to seeking an order of the court dispensing with, or modifying the requirement for, notice: see UCPR r 18.2(2) .

level.toc-caption: [33.4.65] Representation of applicants to set aside a subpoena

heading.title: Representation of applicants to set aside a subpoena

p.text: A person who seeks to set aside a subpoena has the right to appear by counsel: Senior v Holdsworth; Ex parte Independent Television News Ltd [1976] QB 23 at 33; [1975] 2 All ER 1009 ; Christie v Ford (1957) 2 FLR 202 at 204 ; Wilkinson v Wilkinson (1901) 1 SR (NSW) Eq 285 ; Coonan v Richardson [1947] QWN 19 ; and see the discussion in Hogg, Liability of the Crown, Law Book Company, 1971, p 43.
A subpoena must be served personally on the addressee.
The issuing party must serve a copy of a subpoena to produce on each other active party as soon as practicable after the subpoena has been served on the addressee.
[subr (2) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[38], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [33.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.5.

Rule 11.5 permits service of a subpoena outside the state, subject to either leave or confirmation: Arhill Pty Ltd v General Terminal Co Pty Ltd (1990) 23 NSWLR 545 . See annotations to r 11.5 as to service outside Australia. A subpoena may also be served outside the state within Australia under the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth).
Legislation cited in [33.5.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.5, r 33.6(3).

If the subpoena is served at a time which does not comply with r 33.5 , the person served is not obliged to comply with it — unless they have actual knowledge of the contents of the subpoena and its requirements: see r 33.6(3) . Apart from that subrule, the general position is that service should be as early as possible so that the witness is not inconvenienced, but must be served a reasonable time before the witness is required. What is a reasonable time is a matter of fact in each case, but it has been held that service at 11am for a matter to be heard at 2pm is insufficient: Barber v Wood (1838) 2 Mood & R 172, though where the witness was served at noon on the steps of the courthouse and told that he was required at 5pm, service was sufficient: Maunsell v Ainsworth (1840) 8 Dowl 869. See also Hammond v Stewart (1722) 93 ER 667 and R v Smith (1875) LR 10 QB 604.

The ordinary requirement for personal service is particularly appropriate in the case of a subpoena to give evidence. Such a subpoena must be served personally and substituted service is inappropriate: Nash v Stewart [2010] NSWSC 513; BC201003292 . However, in exceptional cases, alternative methods of service may be permissible — for example, under CPA s 14 or UCPR r 10.4: see Sleiman v Afeich [2005] NSWSC 992; BC200507973 (absconding defendants subject to asset preservation orders).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.6] r 33.6 Compliance with subpoena (cf SCR Part 37, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Compliance with subpoena (cf SCR Part 37, rule 6)

p.text: An addressee need not comply with the requirements of a subpoena to attend to give evidence unless conduct money has been handed or tendered to the addressee a reasonable time before the date on which attendance is required.
An addressee need not comply with the requirements of a subpoena unless it is served on or before the date specified in the subpoena as the last date for service of the subpoena.

Despite rule 33.5(1) , an addressee must comply with the requirements of a subpoena even if it has not been served personally on that addressee if the addressee has, by the last date for service of the subpoena, actual knowledge of the subpoena and of its requirements.
The addressee must comply with a subpoena to produce:

by attending at the date, time and place specified for production and producing the subpoena or a copy of it and the document or thing to the court or to the person authorised to take evidence in the proceeding as permitted by the court, or

by delivering or sending the subpoena or a copy of it and the document or thing to the registrar at the address specified for the purpose in the subpoena, so that they are received not less than 2 clear days before the date specified in the subpoena for attendance and production.

In the case of a subpoena that is both a subpoena to attend to give evidence and a subpoena to produce, production of the subpoena or a copy of it and of the document or thing in any of the ways permitted by subrule (4) does not discharge the addressee from the obligation to attend to give evidence.
Unless a subpoena specifically requires the production of the original, the addressee may produce a copy of any document required to be produced by the subpoena.
[subs (6) insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[5], effective 11 December 2009]
The copy of a document may be:
a photocopy, or
in any electronic form that the issuing party has indicated will be acceptable.
[repealed]
[subs (7) insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[5], effective 11 December 2009 ; am Amendment 32 of 2010 Sch 1[3], [4], effective 7 May 2010 ; Amendment 45 of 2011 r 3, effective 10 August 2011]

Procedures relating to the production of, and access to, subpoena material, and especially in relation to production of subpoenaed material in electronic format in Supreme Court proceedings are dealt with in Practice Note SC Gen 18. In the District Court the procedures relating to the return of subpoenas are dealt with in Practice Note DC (Civil) No 8.

Documents produced on subpoena are produced to the court. When calling on a subpoena, counsel should ask that the person subpoenaed be called. The person who answers the call should be sworn as a witness. They should be asked to state their name and address from the body of the court. They should then be asked “Do you produce in answer to a subpoena served on the (X Bank) the documents referred to in the subpoena and the subpoena itself?”. If the answer is in the affirmative, the person is asked to hand the documents to the court officer. The person subpoenaed is then asked (often by the judge), “Do you object to the parties having access to these documents?” If the answer is “No” and both parties agree, the documents are made available to counsel to inspect. If there is an objection, the court must determine the question of inspection in the light of the nature of the objection — and may inspect the documents for the purpose of so doing. See generally “Subpoena duces tecum” by P Moffitt in Glass, Seminars on Evidence, Law Book Company, 1972, p 2 and National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372 and on appeal in National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind (1979) 141 CLR 648; 24 ALR 86 . The issues that may arise in connection with objections to inspection are further discussed in [33.9.5] and [33.9.10] .

Conduct money is defined in r 1 as a sum of money (or its equivalent) that is sufficient to meet the addressee's reasonable expenses of attending (and returning from) court as required by the subpoena. It follows that neither a mere promise to pay, nor an offer of indemnity, satisfies the requirement to provide conduct money. However, it is not necessary to tender money if the subpoena issuer provides its practical equivalent (such a travel tickets and accommodation vouchers).

If conduct money is not provided in accordance with the rule, the addressee need not comply with the subpoena and their refusal to do so cannot found the sanction of arrest or proceedings for contempt: Fuller v Prentice (1788) 126 ER 31; Ashton v Haigh (1814) 2 Chit 201; Harris/D-E Pty Ltd v McClelland's Coffee & Tea Pty Ltd (1999) 149 FLR 204; [1999] NSWSC 36; BC9900331 .

The obligation to provide the addressee with an amount sufficient for reasonable expenses requires the issuer to make some assessment of the amount of the expenses likely to be involved: Foyster v Foyster Holdings Pty Ltd (in liq) [2003] NSWSC 881 . Whether a reasonable sum has been tendered depends upon the particular circumstances. A witness who lives locally, but who has to return from abroad earlier than otherwise, is entitled to the expenses of the return journey even if the trial is in the person's home city: Vice v Anson (1827) 3 C & P 19; Castrucci v Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority (1990) 94 ACTR 1 (witness about to travel interstate was entitled to a return air ticket and a written undertaking to meet further reasonable expenses). Where there is a controversy about either the sufficiency of the amount tendered, or the ability of the issuing party to meet the subpoenaed party’s costs, the court may determine the matter before requiring compliance with the subpoena: see [33.11.10] . In cases of doubt, the tender of a small sum for additional expenses may be prudent: Harris/D-E Pty Ltd v McClelland's Coffee & Tea Pty Ltd, above.

If the trial is cancelled before the witness incurs expenses, the party that served the subpoena is entitled to recover the conduct money in an action for moneys had and received: Martin v Andrews (1856) 26 LJQB 39; 119 ER 1148 .

The obligation to tender conduct money, and the liability for expenses, is that of the party rather than the party's solicitor: Robins v Bridge (1837) 7 LJ Ex 49; 150 ER 1079. But a solicitor who issues a subpoena may be regarded as subject to a professional obligation to ensure that the witness's expenses are met.
Legislation cited in [33.6.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 33.6(4)(b).
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 DCR Pt 43A r 1.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 55 r 13.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 SCA s 121(2), CPA s 13.

A party calling on a person subpoenaed to produce documents may be entitled to test the extent of compliance or sufficiency of the answer to the subpoena or the basis for any objection to production or inspection of the documents. For that purpose, the person answering the subpoena may be required to be sworn and examined. However, the person answering the subpoena does not thereby become a witness in the proceedings. The examination is limited to the sufficiency of the answer to the subpoena. The person is not liable to be cross-examined so as to establish that the circumstances of non-compliance involved contempt: Hexiva Pty Ltd v Lederer [2006] NSWSC 561; BC200605295 at [14]–[15] . Neither is the person liable to general cross-examination by the opposing party: Trade Practices Commission v Arnotts Ltd (No 2) (1989) 21 FCR 306 at 312–15; 88 ALR 90; BC8908420 . Where documents have been produced to a Registrar in the Supreme Court (or a Judicial Registrar in the District Court), including pursuant to UCPR r 33.6(4)(b) , the examination may be conducted before that Registrar: Pyoja Pty Ltd v 284 Bronte Road Developments Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 831; BC200606373 at [9]–[16] and see DCR Pt 43A r 1 . However, a Registrar who constitutes the court for the purpose of such an examination cannot exercise the court’s contempt power to sanction non-compliance. The Supreme Court’s power to punish for contempt is conferred on “the Court” by SCR Pt 55 r 13 and has not been delegated to a Registrar under CPA s 13 or SCA s 121(2) . DCR Pt 43A r 1 similarly restricts the powers of a Judicial Registrar of that court.
Legislation cited in [33.6.17] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 33.12.

Failure to comply with a subpoena, unless lawfully excused, constitutes contempt: see UCPR r 33.12 . Disobedience to a subpoena cannot be dealt with unless the document is proved to exist and to have been in possession and control of the witness at the material time: O’Born v Commissioner for Government Transport (1959) 77 WN (NSW) 81; Ditfort v Brown (1990) 19 NSWLR 49 ; Markisic v Commonwealth [2007] NSWCA 92; BC200702829 at [61] per Campbell JA citing Re Bramblevale Ltd [1970] 1 Ch 128 at 137-8; [1969] 3 All ER 1062 ; Thorpe v Marr’s Furniture Removals Pty Ltd [2000] QSC 279; BC200004790 at [11] ; Wyszynski v Bill [2005] NSWSC 110; BC200501030 at [59]-[61] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.7] r 33.7 Production otherwise than on attendance (cf SCR Part 37, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Production otherwise than on attendance (cf SCR Part 37, rule 7)

p.text: This rule applies if an addressee produces a document or thing in accordance with rule 33.6(4)(b) .
The registrar must, if requested by the addressee, give a receipt for the document or thing to the addressee.
If the addressee produces more than one document or thing, the addressee must, if requested by the registrar, provide a list of the documents or things produced.
The addressee may, with the consent of the issuing party, produce a copy, instead of the original, of any document required to be produced.
The addressee may at the time of production inform the registrar in writing that any document or copy of a document produced need not be returned and may be destroyed.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.8] r 33.8 Removal, return, inspection, copying and disposal of documents and things (cf SCR Part 37, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Removal, return, inspection, copying and disposal of documents and things (cf SCR Part 37, rule 8)

p.text: The court may give directions in relation to the removal from and return to the court, and the inspection, copying and disposal, of any document or thing that has been produced to the court in response to a subpoena.

level.toc-caption: [33.8.5] Photocopy access to subpoena documents — Supreme Court

heading.title: Photocopy access to subpoena documents — Supreme Court

p.text: Photocopy access can often be most conveniently achieved by permitting a party to uplift produced documents and return them upon completion of copying. Practice Note SC Gen 3 applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court and permits a solicitor to appoint an “approved” legal copying firm. Where access is granted to subpoena documents the order is deemed to authorise the solicitor representing the party to appoint an approved firm, authorise the appointed approved firm to uplift the produced documents from the Registry and to oblige the uplifting party to return them within two days. Inspection of the original produced documents may only be undertaken at the registry, unless specific approval is granted by a registrar to inspect documents while they are in the possession of an approved firm.
A list of approved law copier firms under Practice Note SC Gen 3 can be found at http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/supremecourt/approved_legal_copier_firms.html .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.9] r 33.9 Inspection of, and dealing with, documents and things produced otherwise than on attendance (cf SCR Part 37, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Inspection of, and dealing with, documents and things produced otherwise than on attendance (cf SCR Part 37, rule 9)

p.text: This rule applies if an addressee produces a document or thing in accordance with rule 33.6(4)(b) .

On the request in writing of a party, the registrar must inform the party whether production in response to a subpoena has occurred, and, if so, include a description, in general terms, of the documents and things produced.
Subject to this rule, no person may inspect a document or thing produced unless the court has granted leave and the inspection is in accordance with that leave.

Unless the court orders otherwise, the registrar may permit the parties to inspect at the office of the registrar any document or thing produced unless the addressee, a party or any person having sufficient interest objects to the inspection under this rule.

If the addressee objects to a document or thing being inspected by any party to the proceeding, the addressee must, at the time of production, notify the registrar in writing of the objection and of the grounds of the objection.

If a party or person having a sufficient interest objects to a document or thing being inspected by a party to the proceeding, the objector may notify the registrar in writing of the objection and of the grounds of the objection.
On receiving notice of an objection under this rule, the registrar:
must not permit any, or any further, inspection of the document or thing the subject of the objection, and
must refer the objection to the court for hearing and determination.

The registrar must notify the issuing party of the objection and of the date, time and place at which the objection will be heard, and the issuing party must notify the addressee, the objector and each other party accordingly.
The registrar must not permit any document or thing produced to be removed from the office of the registrar except on application in writing signed by the solicitor for a party.
See rule 1.3 (2) with respect to the meaning of the reference to a solicitor for a party.
[subr (9) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 9 June 2006]
A solicitor who signs an application under subrule (9) and removes a document or thing from the office of the registrar, undertakes to the court by force of this rule that:
the document or thing will be kept in the personal custody of the solicitor or a barrister briefed by the solicitor in the proceeding, and
the document or thing will be returned to the registry in the same condition, order and packaging in which it was removed, as and when directed by the registrar.

See rule 1.3(3) with respect to the meaning of the reference to a solicitor who removes a document or thing from the office of the registrar and the reference to the personal custody of the solicitor.
[subr (10) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[13], effective 9 June 2006]
The registrar may, in the registrar’s discretion, grant an application under subrule (9) subject to conditions or refuse to grant the application.

level.toc-caption: [33.9.5] Production of documents in response to a subpoena

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 1.9(3)-(5), UCPR r 21.5, UCPR r 33.4.

heading.title: Production of documents in response to a subpoena

p.text: A subpoena requires the production of documents to the court, rather than to the parties to the proceedings. Formerly, in the absence of an order under UCPR r 33.4 (setting aside or varying the subpoena), objections to inspection — whether based on claims of privilege, confidentiality, relevance or fairness: see generally the notes accompanying UCPR r 21.5 — could not be relied on to justify a refusal to produce the documents to the court. That position is now qualified by UCPR r 1.9(3)-(5) which, though formally providing that a valid privilege claim may afford a sufficient basis for objecting to production even to the court, also provides that the court may compel production for the purpose of ruling on the privilege claim.

level.toc-caption: [33.9.7] Inspection of documents — objections by the subpoena addressee

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.9.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.8.

heading.title: Inspection of documents — objections by the subpoena addressee

p.text: Once documents have been produced in answer to a subpoena it is for the court to determine whether, when and in what circumstances the documents may be made available to the parties: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372. That responsibility may require the court to ensure that affected persons have a proper opportunity to object to inspection (for example to preserve legal professional privilege: Hypec Electronics Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 704; BC200605278 at [5] ; Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [130] [133] . Where the addressee objects to inspection the court may inspect documents if it is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so in order to properly determine the objection: Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Alister v R (1984) 154 CLR 404; 50 ALR 41; BC8300122 ; Zarro v Australian Securities Commission (1992) 36 FCR 40; 10 ACLC 831 : see r 1.8 of the UCPR. Apart from objections based on privilege (as to which see [21.5.55] – [21.5.135] ) the exercise of the court’s discretion in relation to inspection will be influenced by the nature of the documents produced, the ground of objection, their apparent degree of relevance to the proceedings and, to a very limited extent, the state of the proceedings. To illustrate this general proposition, inspection by parties to the proceedings has been refused, deferred or restricted in the following instances:
refusal of inspection — the court not satisfied that access to the documents was required for a legitimate forensic purpose: Alister v R, above ; Saleam v R (1989) 16 NSWLR 14; 39 A Crim R 406 ;
deferral of inspection to afford interested parties an opportunity to be heard: Grgic v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (NSWCA, Kirby P, 5 April 1993, unreported, BC9303677) (protection of privacy interests);

deferral of inspection until the commencement of the trial: for example, National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind, above, at 385–6; Science Research Council v Nasse [1980] AC 1028 at 1078, 1086; [1979] 3 All ER 673 ; Wran v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1984] 3 NSWLR 241 at 250–6 (the “newspaper rule” in defamation proceedings — cf, Hansen v Border Morning Mail Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 27 June 1988, unreported));

inspection restricted to some of the parties: Queensland Mines Ltd v Hudson (1976) ACLC ¶40–266 at 28,664 (non-disclosure of a document likely to have significant impact on the credibility of a party); Victoria v Davies (2003) 6 VR 245; [2003] VSCA 65; BC200302798 at [15] and [19] ; but contrast the general preference for disclosure expressed in Boyes v Colins (2000) 23 WAR 123; [2000] WASCA 344; BC200006872 and [57]–[68] ; and

inspection limited to the parties' legal advisers and independent experts: see, for example, Kimberley Mineral Holdings Ltd (in liq) v McEwan [1980] 1 NSWLR 210; (1980) 4 ACLR 851 ; Travel Compensation Fund v Blair [2004] NSWSC 501; BC200403548 (protection of commercial information by restricted access in preference to masking).

level.toc-caption: [33.9.10] Inspection of documents — objections by a party

heading.title: Inspection of documents — objections by a party

level.toc-caption: [33.9.12] Inspection, objection and compliance — Registrar’s powers

p.text: Legislation cited in [33.9.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 13, CPA s 68.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR rr 33.1–33.13, UCPR r 33.9(7).
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 DCR Pt 43A r 1, DCR 43A.1.

heading.title: Inspection, objection and compliance — Registrar’s powers

p.text: Non contentious inspection and copying of subpoena documents may be dealt with by registrars under the present rule, complemented by the scope of the particular delegations made under CPA s 13 : see [s 13.5] . As to the ordinary procedures for inspection and copying see [33.9.20] . Where there are objections to disclosure and inspection UCPR r 33.9(7) nominally restricts a Registrar’s powers to determine objections to production, but this apparent limitation is likely to be regarded as overcome by the more specific delegation of powers under CPA s 13 : see [17,000] Delegation to Registrars (which appears immediately after the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999); or (in the case of a Judicial Registrar of the District Court) by DCR Pt 43A r 1 . Where a question arises as to the sufficiency of the answer to a subpoena a registrar of the Supreme Court may exercise all of the court’s powers under CPA s 68 and UCPR rr 33.1–33.13 . These include the power to determine the sufficiency of the addressee’s compliance: see [33.6.15] , but not the power to sanction non-compliance as contempt: Pyoja Pty Ltd v 284 Bronte Road Developments Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 831; BC200606373 at [17] . (The same applies to a Judicial Registrar in the District Court: see DCR 43A.1 .)
Legislation cited in [33.9.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 21.5.

Any inspection of subpoenaed documents carries with it an implied undertaking to use the documents, or information contained in them, only for purposes directly connected with the conduct of the litigation: see annotations to UCPR r 21.5 . In order to complement that implication, where documents are inspected in the court registry, it is common to require the person inspecting the documents to provide a written undertaking in terms similar to the following:

“Except with the leave of the court I will not otherwise than for the purpose of the proceedings mentioned beside my signature, divulge, communicate or refer to any person any information obtained from inspection of any document or thing produced by the court to me or a copy of any document or thing so produced to and inspected by me, unless it is admitted into evidence in the proceedings.”
Legislation cited in [33.9.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.3, r 1.3(3)(iv), r 33.9(10), r 33.9(9).

Inspection involving removal of documents from the court registry may be authorised by a registrar under UCPR r 33.9(9) . Where inspection involves a solicitor for one of the parties making an application (under UCPR r 33.9(9) ) to remove the documents from the registry, the solicitor thereby undertakes the personal obligations set out in UCPR r 33.9(10) in relation to the custody, condition and return of the documents. (However, the personal custody obligation is given an extended meaning by UCPR r 1.3 and permits inspection by employed solicitors and approved photocopying firms.)

In the Supreme Court, inspection and copying may be carried out by an approved legal copying firm (see UCPR r 1.3(3)(iv) and Practice Note SC Gen 3 . A list of approved law copier firms under Practice Note SC Gen 3 can be found at http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/ supremecourt/approved_legal_copier_firms.html ). In the District Court, the ordinary procedure for inspection is dealt with in Practice Note DC (Civil) No 8 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.10] r 33.10 Disposal of documents and things produced (cf SCR Part 37, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Disposal of documents and things produced (cf SCR Part 37, rule 10)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, the registrar may, in the registrar’s discretion, return to the addressee any document or thing produced in response to a subpoena.

Unless the court orders otherwise, the registrar must not return any document or thing under subrule (1) unless the registrar has given to the issuing party at least 14 days’ notice of the intention to do so and that period has expired.
[subr (3) rep Amendment 50 of 2011 r 3, effective 9 December 2011]
The addressee must complete the notice and declaration in the subpoena and produce the subpoena (or copy of the subpoena) with the documents produced to the court under the subpoena.
[subr (4) subst Amendment 50 of 2011 r 3, effective 9 December 2011]

Subject to subrule (6), the registrar may, on the expiry of 4 months from the conclusion of the proceeding, cause to be destroyed all the documents produced in the proceedings in compliance with a subpoena, that were declared by the addressee to be copies.
[subr (5) insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[6], effective 11 December 2009]

The registrar may cause to be destroyed those documents, declared by the addressee to be copies, that have become exhibits in the proceeding when they are no longer required in connection with the proceeding, including on any appeal.
[subr (6) insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[6], effective 11 December 2009]

level.toc-caption: [33.10.5] Disposal of photocopied subpoena documents and documents in electronic format

heading.title: Disposal of photocopied subpoena documents and documents in electronic format

p.text: The courts may destroy photocopied material that has been produced on subpoena when it is no longer required. Original documents will be returned to the producing party. To facilitate this, issuing parties must attach to the front of a subpoena a notice and declaration in approved form that must be completed by the addressee and attached to the subpoena or copy of the subpoena that accompanies the produced documents. For form of subpoena notice and declaration see Form 26A (Subpoena to produce with subpoena notice and declaration) and Form 27A (Subpoena to attend to give evidence and produce with subpoena notice and declaration).

The procedures in the Supreme Court relating to subpoenaed material provided in electronic format are set out in Practice Note SC Gen 18 — Production of and access to subpoenaed material and returning exhibits and subpoenaed material in civil proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.11] r 33.11 Costs and expenses of compliance (cf SCR Part 37, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Costs and expenses of compliance (cf SCR Part 37, rule 11)

p.text: The court may order the issuing party to pay the amount of any reasonable loss or expense incurred in complying with the subpoena.
If an order is made under subrule (1), the court must fix the amount or direct that it be fixed in accordance with the court’s usual procedure in relation to costs.
An amount fixed under this rule is separate from and in addition to:
any conduct money paid to the addressee, and
any witness expenses payable to the addressee.

The court may order that the expenses ordered under this rule include an allowance for the time and expenses incurred in dealing with the subpoena: Deposit & Investment Co Ltd (Receivers Appointed) v Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co (1996) 39 NSWLR 267 at 289 (expenses may be ordered at the addressee's usual charge out rate); J Aron Corp v Newmont Yandal Operations [2004] NSWSC 996 . That allowance is not restricted to the time actually spent in court: Danieletto v Khera (1995) 35 NSWLR 684 . The expenses which may be compensated for include the cost of legal advice reasonably incurred in obtaining advice in relation to confidentiality and privilege issues concerning the subpoenaed documents: Fuelxpress Ltd v LM Ericsson Pty Ltd (1987) 75 ALR 284 ; Hadid v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 65 FCR 350; 144 ALR 73 ; Chapman v Luminis Pty Ltd (No 3) (2000) 104 FCR 368; [2000] FCA 1120; BC200004508 ; Marsden v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd [2001] NSWSC 77; BC200100502 ; Re Panna Pharmaceuticals Ltd; Selim v McGrath (2004) 48 ACSR 681 at [40]–[43] . Relevant expenses may include the reasonable cost of photocopying or printing for the purpose of retaining copies of the documents: Mancorp Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Pty Ltd (SASC, Debelle J, 5 March 1993, unreported, BC9300346); A Pty Ltd v Z [2007] NSWSC 999; BC200708185 at [45] . Where a firm of solicitors receives a subpoena it is entitled to recover as loss or expense the time spent by the partners and employees at charge out rates: Deposit & Investment Co Ltd (Receivers Appointed) v Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co (1996) 39 NSWLR 267 at 289ff; BC9600487 ; A Pty Ltd v Z [2007] NSWSC 999; BC200708185 at [45] ; Re Dovico; Ex parte Mayne Wetherall (2012) 265 FLR 445; [2012] NSWSC 822; BC201205333 at [36]ff (NZ firm of solicitors — “profit costs” allowed). The form of the rule suggests that a claim for costs and expenses may be made by motion in the proceedings in which the subpoena was issued: cf Bank of New South Wales v Withers (1981) 35 ALR 21; 52 FLR 207 . If the person subpoenaed unsuccessfully asserts a claim of client legal (or other) privilege, costs of any contested hearing to resolve the claim may be awarded against them: Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) (2006) 67 NSWLR 289; [2006] NSWSC 879; BC200606784 .

Ordinarily the question of expenses will be determined after compliance with the subpoena — unless there is evidence establishing a genuine doubt about the ability of the issuing party to meet any order for expenses: Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 253; BC200602079 at [15]–[16] . In cases of that kind the court may require the issuing party to provide security for the subpoenaed person’s reasonable costs of compliance: Burrup Fertilisers Pty Ltd (recs and mgrs apptd) v Oswal (No 6) (2012) 205 FCR 429; 292 ALR 94; [2012] FCA 590; BC201203899 (issuing party an overseas resident with no assets in Australia).
Legislation cited in [33.11.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.33.
The parties concerned must attempt to agree on the amount of the reasonable loss or expenses incurred in complying with the subpoena before seeking an order under the present rule: see UCPR r 42.33 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.12] r 33.12 Failure to comply with subpoena — contempt of court (cf SCR Part 37, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Failure to comply with subpoena — contempt of court (cf SCR Part 37, rule 12)

p.text: Failure to comply with a subpoena without lawful excuse is a contempt of court and the addressee may be dealt with accordingly.

Despite rule 33.5(1) , if a subpoena has not been served personally on the addressee, the addressee may be dealt with for contempt of court as if the addressee had been so served if it is proved that the addressee had, by the last date for service of the subpoena, actual knowledge of the subpoena and of its requirements.

Subrules (1) and (2) are without prejudice to any power of the court under any rules of the court (including any rules of the court providing for the arrest of an addressee who defaults in attendance in accordance with a subpoena) or otherwise, to enforce compliance with a subpoena.
Legislation cited in [33.12.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 97.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 194.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 42.27.

Disobedience to a subpoena enlivens the arrest powers conferred by CPA s 97 and by s 194 of the Evidence Act 1995. The arrested person may be subject to examination for the purpose of determining the sufficiency of any compliance with the subpoena: see [33.6.15] . Deliberate disobedience in failing to comply with a subpoena constitutes contempt of court: Ditfort v Brown (1990) 19 NSWLR 49 ; Price v Hutchinson (1870) LR 9 Eq 534; Ullathorne, Hartridge & Co Ltd v Green (1901) 27 VLR 22 . It is conventionally described as a criminal contempt: James v Cowan; Re Botten (1929) 42 CLR 305; (1928) 3 ALJR 170 ; R v Daye [1908] 2 KB 333; R v S (1988) 50 SASR 161 . (Similarly, interference with service of subpoena by, for example, abusing or intimidating the person attempting to serve it may constitute contempt: Re Barnes [1968] 1 NSWR 697; (1968) 87 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 479 ). In the case of a subpoena addressed to a corporation, the corporation may be punished for contempt, and so too may be any “proper officer” of the corporation who is responsible for the non-compliance: Attorney-General for Tuvalu v Philatelic Distribution Corp Ltd [1990] 2 All ER 216 at 223-4; [1990] 1 WLR 926 at 937-9 ; R v Ronen (2004) 62 NSWLR 707 at [95]–[107] . Apart from punishment for contempt, a witness who fails to answer a subpoena may be liable for costs and damages to the party on whose behalf the subpoena was issued: Roberts v J & F Stone Lighting & Radio Ltd (1945) 172 LT 240 ; UCPR r 42.27 ; UCPR r 42.27 .

level.toc-caption: [33.12.10] Disobedience to subpoena to produce — proof of

heading.title: Disobedience to subpoena to produce — proof of

p.text: Mere non-production of documents that are called for by a subpoena, or other court order to produce documents, is insufficient to establish that there has been a contempt. In addition, it needs to be established that, at the date for production the alleged contemnor had documents that met the description of the documents called for (Re Bramblevale Ltd [1970] 1 Ch 128 at 137-8; [1969] 3 All ER 1062 ; Thorpe v Marr’s Furniture Removals Pty Ltd [2000] QSC 279; BC200004790 at [11] ; Wyszynski v Bill [2005] NSWSC 110; BC200501030 at [59]-[61] ) and wilful disobedience, in the sense of deliberate action or inaction that is not casual, accidental, or unintentional (Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union v Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 98 at 111-13; 66 ALR 577; BC8601455 ; Fairclough v Manchester Ship Canal Co [1897] WN 7; 41 SJ 225 ): Markisic v Commonwealth [2007] NSWCA 92; BC200702829 at [61]-[64] per Campbell JA (Dismissing an appeal from a finding that a suspicion about the degree of commitment to the task of responding to the subpoena, was insufficient to discharge the criminal onus at [65]-[68]). Each element in the charge whether the charge is classified as alleging a criminal contempt or a civil contempt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt: Markisic above at [60] citing Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 534; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 33.13] r 33.13 Documents and things in the custody of a court (cf SCR Part 37, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Documents and things in the custody of a court (cf SCR Part 37, rule 13)

p.text: A party who seeks production of a document or thing in the custody of the court or of another court may inform the registrar in writing accordingly, identifying the document or thing.
If the document or thing is in the custody of the court, the registrar must produce the document or thing:
in court or to any person authorised to take evidence in the proceeding, as required by the party, or
as the court directs.
If the document or thing is in the custody of another court, the registrar must, unless the court has otherwise ordered:
request the other court to send the document or thing to the registrar, and
after receiving it, produce the document or thing:
in court or to any person authorised to take evidence in the proceeding as required by the party, or
as the court directs.

level.toc-caption: [33.13.5] Production of documents held by the court

heading.title: Production of documents held by the court

p.text: It is not appropriate to issue a subpoena to obtain the production of documents that are held by the court or are part of the court's records. If such documents are relevant to the proceedings, their production may be obtained by a request to the court registry officers. Rather than issue a subpoena, the appropriate course is for a request to go from one part of the court to another: B v N (1994) 35 NSWLR 140 at 144 (Protective Commissioner — treated as master of the Supreme Court — appropriateness of issuing a subpoena).
